pageContext.title: Tech media site raises $1m from Wavemaker, Grvty Media, and more
pageContext.content:
Image credit: 36Kr

Technology business media site KrAsia has raised US$1 million in seed funding from investors, its public filing shows, giving it a valuation of roughly US$3 million. Singapore-based KrAsia is a subsidiary of 36Kr, China’s leading startup media property.

KrAsia’s investors from the city-state include venture capital firm Wavemaker Pacific as well as Grvty Media, which runs a number of consumer-oriented media properties, including Vulcan Post and Millennials of Singapore. Chinese VC firm 01VC was part of the round as well.

36Kr, which operates under the legal name Beijing Pinxin Media Culture, is the biggest shareholder. Here’s the cap table:

Shareholder Ownership Amount invested (US$)
Beijing Pinxin Media Culture (36Kr) 45% –
Ma Cheng 20% –
01VC Poseidon Fund 1 15% 453,000
Grvty Media 10% 302,000
Wavemaker Pacific 1 5% 151,000
Taklamakan Holdings 5% 151,000

36Kr has been expanding rapidly into other business lines and regions. In addition to running a co-working space, it also just launched a venture capital fund and recently set up a business in Japan.

Like Tech in Asia and e27, KrAsia provides Asia-wide, English language coverage about the technology and startup scene. DealStreetAsia covers the space as well, alongside content about the private equity industry. A number of media companies like Bloomberg, TechCrunch, and South China Morning Post also cover the industry.

In addition to these entities, there are plenty of country-specific, English language tech news sites like The Ken in India and Technode in China.

KrAsia did not respond to our request for comment.

seo.title: KrAsia raised $1m from Wavemaker, Grvty Media, and more
seo.description: The site joins Tech in Asia and e27 in providing coverage about the technology and startup scene in Asia.
